everybody: as you know I have this commit chain: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941/
it is a little bit inconsistent now as it reflects two different ideas (inconsistent = code not rebased because it needs manual merge). which do you prefer?
1) have an error handling 'framework' similar to the current way of error handling where one can create his/her own error using Errorf("anything") (errors.Errorf instead of fmt.Errorf)
2) have one that supports multiple languages but with predefined errors read from a json file where there is a mapping of ERROR_CODEs, languages and error messages
Please tell me what you think.
file.preview_highlight:
everybody: as you know I have this commit chain: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941/
it is a little bit inconsistent now as it reflects two different ideas (inconsistent = code not rebased because it needs manual merge). which do you prefer?
1) have an error handling 'framework' similar to the current way of error handling where one can create his/her own error using Errorf("anything") (errors.Errorf instead of fmt.Errorf)
2) have one that supports multiple languages but with predefined errors read from a json file where there is a mapping of ERROR_CODEs, languages and error messages
Please tell me what you think.

text: please help us decide which is the right way to do it, thank you :slightly_smiling_face:
sure

<@U1AU8DRQR>  I believe one to one mapping between error codes and error messages would not be possible as one error code might result in different error messages. For example, AUTH_ERROR might be caused by an invalid password, an unknown user name or a locked account and you might want to give a slightly different message in each case. (AUTH_ERROR is just an example, some error codes will have only one possible message but others might have more than one possible messages). Error codes should represent a broader category of errors not individual error messages

I could give example of database error codes, see <https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.2/static/errcodes-appendix.html> the error codes are categorized in different classes and each class has set of error codes
<@U1Y2R5C9L> good point. but we can also have hierarchical error codes, e.g. one for db errors, another for one specific category and another for one specific case
e.g. 949 (or 404 :slightly_smiling_face: )

IMO, the error code is useful in client server invocation. Server should provide error definition. But for SDK, it is just in client app, define different type exception should be better choice. That is described in the book 《clean code》
how do you mean that the server should provide error definition?
i mean if two process coMmunication error code is useful and usually server side define the error code list such as postgresql example.
yes
and I agree that client side and server side should be handled differently

basically the peer container cannot connect to the Docker endpoint  `CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock`
yep
you'll need to actually mount the socket as a volume -

```
membersrvc:
  image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc
  ports:
    - "7054:7054"
  command: membersrvc
vp0:
  image: hyperledger/fabric-peer
  ports:
    - "7050:7050"
    - "7051:7051"
    - "7052:7052"
  volumes:
    - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
  environment:
    - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true
    - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock
    - CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG
    - CORE_PEER_ID=vp0
    - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=test_vp0
    - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=MwYpmSRjupbT
  links:
    - membersrvc
  command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start"
```

<@U2SE05657> Here is what I tried and it works (I assume you are in windows)
1. Right Click on "My Computer"
2. Click on "Properties"
3. Click on "Advanced Properties"
4. Click on "Environment Variables"
5. Define new "System" variable (in the box at the bottom), enter GOPATH in the variable name and whatever value you have in the variable value
6. Restart the IDEA
Now if you execute ```System.out.println("GOPATH = "+System.getenv("GOPATH"));``` it should give you a valid value

Please try this and let us know how it goes. If it does not work, we might consider adding a System Property for users who don't have aceess to environment variables

<@U2N1D7C07> This is new SDK and there has been no release so far. Currently, this implements the following functionalities:
1. Enrolling and registering members
2. Deploying, invoking and querying chain code - GOLANG and Java chaincodes are supported, security should be disabled - no TCerts

The SDK APIs are still being designed and the focus is to implement the V1 APIs, since a lot in the V1 space is not yet clear in the crypto and membership services domain, it could be a while before you get a fully functional SDK.
If you could let us know what APIs you are specifically after, we may be able to prioritize them sooner

Hi I'm working on the V1 side of the API.  I had targeted to deliver something end of the week for review but partially due to server side changes that's looking more like Monday. There will definitely be changes to this API implementation to conform to spec that will impact anyone building on it.

<@U13TWBRBL> <@U2Q0HP4HY> <@U0YQK8WSV> <@U1Y2R5C9L> just reviewed yesterday's discussion
I'm glad to see that we are trying to collaborate more - this is goodness
I think, though, that there needs to be a change in how we work to enable this level of collaboration

I went through this with the IBM squads, TBH (and some are still being coached;-) so this is not uncommon problem in learning how to be most effective at collaborating in open source with people not sitting in the same office
point one: submit smaller changesets that move the ball slightly, rather than trying to merge a major refactor all at once in the midst of a moving target project as large and as active as Fabric
by small, I mean less than 200 LOC ideally, _with tests_
this could mean that you are adding refactored capability that is not fully enabled excepting via tests until the new capability is fully ready to be activated (eg via feature flag, etc)
Why do I say small? Because smaller changesets means quicker review - a 1k LOC changeset could take a weekend to review
point two: as was suggested above, share the planning and decompose work in discrete tasks that can be independently worked
you can, for instance, write a new function, add its tests (both happy path and the various negative tests) independent of any USE of that new function excepting by the tests
then, once that is merged, you can start to add the calls to the new function (you can even mete this out gradually, again, adding tests where appropriate
May I add we should be opening up JIRA's that describe the work we are doing so it's clearly communicated
absolutely, that is implied in my comment immediately above

if there needs to be a major refactor, then I would strongly recommend that it be discussed in slack or email and that the the agreed approach be documented in JIRA and assignments (short ones!) be meted out
it is important to have as much transparency as possible
and it is important that the changes be incremental so that the disagreements (inevitable) can be minimized
I'd also recommend that there be consideration of adding more maintainers to help with reviews - maybe change the policy to 2+2 to ensure agreement
finally, we should really get Jenkins CI set up for this project
<@U0KM61BCP> Thx for suggestions.. we will definitely start using JIRA to get broader community involvement and to add more committers.  CI is on my todo list.

text: <@U31A496G2> since multiple applications can be sending transactions simultaneously concurrency control can only be done on the peer side, during simulation (by executing the target chaincode) mvcc is built on the state properties touched by that chaincode execution (both read and write)
during validation (in VSCC) the mvcc is checked to root out double spending situations
